repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Forest Resources Management,
            Silk Development Pilot, and Agricultural Services Innovation
            & Reform Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This assessment generally concurred with
            the completion report ratings for the three projects, with
            the following exceptions: the institutional development
            impact was rated as substantial for all projects, for the
            Silk Development Pilot Project, the PPAR found the outcome
            to be moderately satisfactory; and for the Agricultural
            Services Innovation and Reform Project the PPAR found the
            outcome to be moderately satisfactory and the Bank's
            performance to be satisfactory.  All three projects
            contributed to pro-poor growth, though to varying degrees.
            Four specific lessons regarding the pro-poor growth
            challenge, and a final lesson related to the Bank's
            strategy for Bangladesh's rural sector have emerged
            from this review: a) dedicated focus on enhancing
            productivity pays off; b) socially inclusive rural
            development need not constrain rapid agricultural growth; c)
            government-civil society partnerships can enable gains in
            development capacity, both for social inclusion and for
            agricultural growth; d) to enhance benefits for women and
            the poor, project formulation needs the systematic
            integration of measures to achieve this; and e) the
            Bank's rural project portfolio in Bangladesh would
            merit scaling-up, prioritizing, a longer-term program
            approach, and a better strategic framework.

TF021075-POPULATION & HEALTH OFFICE (PHO),TF022055-ENVIRONMENTAL INITIATIVE FOR ASIA/WID,TF024700-NORWEGIAN SUPPORT TO THE ENVIR. DEPT.,TF026530-TAGPE - ENVIR. TECHNICAL
            ASSISTANCE FUND,TF029466-PHRD-SILK DEVLEOPMENT PROJ.(BANK-EXEC.),TF029556-PHRD-SILK DEV. PROJ. (RECIPIENT-EXEC.),TF033705-BANGLADESH - AGRICULTURE,TF034846-BANGLADESH - SILK DEVELOPMENT
            PILOT PROJECT,TF040698-BANGLADESH: SILK DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF037274-BANGLADESH - AG SERV INNOV
            & REFO

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, but only modest
            institutional development impacts. Lessons highlight
            primarily, the need for greater discretionary authority,
            regarding availability of funds, and decisions on costs, and
            expenses, as it relates to the timing for an effective
            plantation management, and optimal forest product yields,
            particularly, in a country such as Bangladesh, whose current
            system of budgetary allocation, and control precludes a
            timely funding. It is thus strongly suggested, that future
            projects involving industrial plantation development, and
            management, include definitive measures, in addition to the
            necessary legal covenants, to ensure these shortcomings are
            overcome: the establishment of a financially autonomous
            entity, having a commercial management approach with the
            Government, local communities, and possibly in partnership
            with the private sector, is an avenue worth exploring. While
            the project demonstrated that mangrove establishment on
            accreted silt beds, can stabilize these beds, and lead to
            the formation of new land masses, suitable for agriculture,
            the sustainable management of mangrove plantations however,
            will depend on such practice being a sound legal basis for
            tenure, with agreed policies for mangrove disposition. But,
            the effective development of forests, and protection of
            wildlife will not be possible, without appropriate
            consideration of the needs, and the involvement of marginal
            populations adjacent to the forests.

18155441.theme: Other environment and natural resources management,Participation and civic engagement
18155441.trustfund:
TF026530-TAGPE - ENVIR. TECHNICAL
            ASSISTANCE FUND,TF022055-ENVIRONMENTAL INITIATIVE FOR ASIA/WID,TF024700-NORWEGIAN SUPPORT TO THE ENVIR. DEPT.,TF021075-POPULATION & HEALTH OFFICE (PHO)
18155441.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The project's primary objectives
            will be to establish and maintain a forest management system
            that is fully responsive to the economic, environmental and
            social goals of the country; to improve the productivity of
            Government owned forests in order to meet the country's
            wood and energy needs; and to protect the country's
            environment.  This will be achieved by: (1) improving and
            further institutionalizing the forest resource information
            management system; (2) integrating environment and
            socio-economic factors and criteria into resource management
            and utilization; (3) carrying out a pilot scheme for
            people's participation in forest development; (4)
            expanding the countries forest resources through plantation
            establishment and improved management; (5) formulating
            management plans for nature conservation areas and
            supporting investments in selected sanctuaries and parks;
            (6) streamlining the organization of the Forest Department,
            and creating within the Department a new responsibility for
            environmental management; (7) providing support for
            professional and technical education and training, and more
            mangrove research. The project will finance civil works,
            vehicles, boats, equipment, furniture, materials service
            contracts, technical assistance, training, labor, and
            incremental staff and operating costs.
